data.title: Eli Lilly: The Price Upside Just Increased
data.description:
When I last wrote about obesity treatment provider Eli Lilly (LLY) a couple of weeks ago, there was still 20% upside to the stock for the remainder of the year. Until the end of yesterday's trading session, the stock had barely moved since, suggesting that the upside was sustained.

Come today, however, and the upside has now jumped to over 25%. Why? With its Q3 2025 results released, the company has raised earnings guidance. The development has gone down well with investors, with the stock up by more than 3% in today's session as I write. Here I discuss the latest quarterly numbers and guidance, but also point out risks to the outlook, which could impact the outlook negatively.

Robust Q3 2025 results

There's much to like about Eli Lilly's Q3 2025 results, starting with revenue growth. Among the first three quarters of 2025, the number saw its strongest increase in Q3 2025 of 54% YoY. As a result, the company's YTD revenue growth is now at 46% YoY.

The company's diabetes and weight loss treatments, Mounjaro and Zepbound respectively, expectedly led the revenue growth. While Mounjaro more than doubled, rising by 109% YoY, Zepbound rose by an even bigger 185% YoY in Q3 2025.

While the non-GAAP gross margin at 83.6%, was slightly lower than the 84.1% level seen year-to-date, there's still much to like about it. First, the gross profit grew by a strong 56% YoY. Also, it's an improvement over the 82.2% margin seen in Q3 2024. This year, the company has also started reporting a non-GAAP margin called the performance margin, which is similar to the operating margin. This number too, looks good, as it rose to 48.3% in Q3 2025 compared with 45.9% in Q2 2025.

Increased guidance

The company's non-GAAP EPS increase was even bigger, by almost 6x YoY, resulting in a guidance upgrade. Starting with revenues, the company has raised guidance by 3.7% at the midpoint, and now expects the number to land in the range of USD 63-65 billion. The guidance range for the performance margin has also been increased, based on higher expectations from sales.

Importantly, the non-GAAP EPS to come in the range of USD 23-23.7 in 2025. After a disappointment in Q1 2025, when Eli Lilly actually lowered guidance, it has now seen two consecutive quarters of an improved outlook. At the midpoint of this range, the expected adjusted EPS has exceeded even the midpoint of the initial guidance range of USD 22.5-24. At USD 0.1, the increase in midpoint is less than 0.5% increase, but the upgrade definitely looks better compared to the prior guidance. It's up by 4.4% at the midpoint.

Market multiples look good

At the midpoint of the latest guidance range, LLY's forward non-GAAP P/E ratio comes to 34.84x. This is favorable compared to the stock's five-year average of 44.15x. As mentioned at the start, this indicates over 25% upside to the stock even now.

Considering that the guidance has been upgraded for two consecutive quarters, it's also instructive to consider how the stock looks if the EPS comes in at the top end of the guidance range. The picture doesn't change much, with the forward P/E now at 34.3x, with the Buy case sustaining for the short term.

Risks to outlook

However, there are also risks to the outlook. The first of them is a possible agreement with the US government, as peers like Pfizer (PFE) and AstraZeneca (AZN) have done recently. If it does come through, treatment prices are likely to be lower, which in turn can reduce margins. As I had pointed out in the previous article on Eli Lilly though, its margins have shown remarkable resilience in the past despite price reductions for Zepbound. But whether it happens again remains to be seen.

A more concrete, though minuscule, drag on earnings can be the company's recent purchase of the clinical stage company, Adverum Biotechnologies (ADVM), which is developing therapies for ocular diseases. Eli Lilly intends to make a cash payment of USD 3.56 per share for the acquisition, which comes to a total of USD 74.4 million.

This doesn't make a significant dent to the company's earnings, but it does shave off some USD 0.08 from the EPS. Assuming that the payout shows up in the non-GAAP figures, the reduction from the midpoint of the guidance range wouldn't merit a change in outlook. And considering the company's robust earnings performance YTD, chances are that it can still continue to report an EPS towards the top end of the guidance range.

However, on the achievement of milestones, the payout per share can rise to as much as USD 12.47, which, of course, can have a more significant impact on the EPS. But whether these targets, based on the treatment's approval and sales goals, are met will only be known only over the years. In other words, the expense won't impact a single year's earnings.

Still, keeping these risks in mind, it's worth considering whether the stock's prospects change if the EPS comes in at the lower end of the guidance range. Turns out, LLY isn't particularly worse off. The forward P/E rises to just 35.37x, which is still significantly below the five-year average.

What's next?

Two weeks ago, there appeared to be a downside risk to Eli Lilly's earnings as an agreement with the US government was slated to be around the corner. Instead, it has delivered an earnings upgrade, backed by a robust performance in Q3 2025. The margins remain strong, and non-GAAP EPS growth has been exceptional.

No matter how the latest guidance is looked at, the stock continues to look attractive even in the short term. This is despite the company's recent purchase of Adverum Biotechnologies, which isn't expected to make any meaningful dent in earnings. But the risk of lowering prices, as its peers have recently done, still persists.

We don't know what happens on that front next. Based on the information that is available, though, the prospects for Eli Lilly have only improved at the stock markets. For this reason, I'm retaining a Strong Buy on LLY.

data.title: ICVT: Bond ETF Outperforming The Stock Market In 2025
data.description:
This article updates my review published in November 2024 in light of current holdings and recent performance.

ICVT strategy

iShares Convertible Bond ETF (ICVT) was launched on 06/02/2015 and tracks the Bloomberg Barclays U.S. Convertible Cash Pay Bond > $250MM Index. ICVT has 364 holdings, a 30-day SEC yield of 1.09%, a trailing 12-month distribution yield of 1.77% and an expense ratio of 0.20%.

As described in the prospectus by iShares, the underlying index exclusively includes cash pay convertible bonds, a class of convertible bonds with an option to convert into shares of the issuer’s common stock (conversion is not mandatory). Other categories of convertible bonds (zero coupon, preferred and mandatory convertible bonds) are not eligible. Additionally, eligible securities must be U.S. dollar-denominated, have at least 31 days until maturity and $250 million of outstanding face value. There is no requirement on credit rating. The index is weighted based on market capitalization and rebalanced on a monthly basis. The portfolio turnover rate was 25% in the most recent fiscal year and 22% in the previous year.

Convertible bonds are often used by growth-oriented companies, because optionality allows them to borrow money at a lower rate, and possibly avoid paying the principal, should the bond be converted. Optionality is also attractive for lenders willing to mix fixed income and speculation on share price. Convertible bonds are hybrid assets, so we can expect ICVT behavior to be between equity and fixed income.

Portfolio

The fund is mostly invested in securities issued by U.S. companies (about 85% of asset value). Non-rated securities represents 75% of assets, while 17% has an investment grade and 5% is below investment grade. The weighted-average yield to maturity is 1.94% and the weighted-average maturity is 3.36 years (85% of assets has a maturity below 5 years). The sensitivity to rate variations is quite low, with an effective duration of 1.09 years.

The portfolio overweights the information technology sector (37.8% of asset value) and has significant exposure in consumer cyclicals (22.5%). Other sectors are below 8%.

The fund is diversified and risks related to individual companies are low. The top 10 issuers, listed in the next table, represent 20.2% of asset value, and the heaviest name weighs about 3%.

Performance

The next table compares performance and risk metrics since 6/9/2015 of ICVT, a stock benchmark (SPY) and a corporate bond benchmark (LQD). ICVT is clearly closer to stocks than to bonds. It has underperformed SPY by 4.3 percentage points in annualized return, with similar volatility (measured as standard deviation of monthly return) and a slightly deeper maximum drawdown.

However, ICVT is 5.4 percentage points ahead of SPY over the last 12 months, due to its high exposure in technology and consumer discretionary growth companies.

Based on historical data, the distribution is very variable and looks quite unpredictable. Unlike most bond ETFs, ICVT doesn’t match the needs of income investors. It is best-suited for investors seeking diversified capital appreciation, or a tactical allocation instrument (this is how I use it).

Competitors

The next table compares characteristics of ICVT and two close competitors:

  • SPDR Bloomberg Convertible Securities ETF (CWB)

ICVT has the lowest expense ratio and is in second position for size (in assets under management), liquidity (in dollar volume) and total return. CWB is the best performer, but the gaps in annualized return and volatility are moderate.

Takeaway

iShares Convertible Bond ETF (ICVT) holds over 300 cash pay convertible bonds, with a focus on growth companies. The return and risk metrics of ICVT are closer to stocks than to bonds. ICVT has lagged the S&P 500 since 2015, but has greatly outperformed it in some periods, like in 2020 and over the last 12 months. Although its holdings are classified as fixed income assets, the yield and distribution history of ICVT aren’t attractive for income investors. It is best suited for diversified growth portfolios or tactical allocation strategies. ICVT is a holding of my Bond Rotation strategy. This position is evaluated once a week and I may have sold it by the time you read this (members of my Investing Group will be notified).

data.title: Sirius XM: The Bottom Is In
data.description:
Q3/25 earnings review

A superficial glance at Sirius XM Holdings Inc.'s (SIRI) Q3/25 earnings release (slides, transcript) doesn't look that exciting, and on its own probably doesn't justify the subsequent 10% rally of the stock.

I've just read again my notes on Q2 '25 (the title was a cautious "There is Hope"), and I could almost copy the article, change some numbers and have my Q3 review ready. But after Q2, the stock slumped heavily.

So what has changed?

Total (Sirius XM plus Pandora) revenues and adj. EBITDA were down slightly again, and so were subscriber numbers (both paying and trial subscribers). Self-pay subscribers were down even at Pandora. At the same time subscriber acquisition costs soared 19%. And despite the recent price increase ARPU was barely flat.

A glimpse of hope could be seen in the promotional trial funnel at Sirius XM, which increased a tiny bit during the quarter, although it remained down YoY.

As usual, the company managed to compensate for the lower subscriber numbers and acquisition cost increases by cutting other expenses, so that overall margins were also just slightly down YoY.

Given continued cost discipline and the already announced lower capex levels, the company could slightly increase its guidance by $25m across the board for revenue, adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow to:

• Total revenue of approximately $8.525 billion,

• Adjusted EBITDA of approximately $2.625 billion, and

• Free cash flow of approximately $1.225 billion.

Net debt was also reduced slightly during the quarter, and interest expenses are falling compared to recent times. All in all, the market probably sees the light at the end of the tunnel.

Given lower promotional activity related to Sirius XM's streaming service, further subscriber losses were expected. The market probably also feared increasing churn in the overall subscriber base, but churn was stable. Moreover, the minimal subscriber loss of just 40,000 confirmed the recent trend of improving subscriber losses. Given less promotion, a loss of just 40,000 subs could hint to the possibility that, with just the streaming issue further behind, Sirius XM could even be able to grow its subscriber base again.

As a result of it all, the market probably started to believe that Sirius XM will not only deliver $1.225B of FCF in 2025, but also the long-term guidance of $1.5B in 2027, given that capex is scheduled to decrease substantially from the currently high level:

With $150m less satellite capex, another $50m reduction of non-satellite capex, and lower interest payments due to lower debt levels, the company effectively needs very little growth to reach its targets: This year's $1.225B guidance plus $200m of capex reduction, plus about $75m of interest savings already makes exactly $1.5B with zero growth.

Sirius XM will reduce leverage by about 0.5x EBITDA by 2027, which means a net debt reduction of about $1.3B. This also looks very achievable, given the current and expected FCF level.

Some near-term excitement

In my view, one of the main drivers of today's rally was probably the talk around the company's spectrum assets. Since Sirius XM (roughly speaking) owns about twice as much spectrum as it needs, there is a huge monetization opportunity. While an outright sale is complicated, probably not even smart to do (as it would create some technical and regulatory problems), the fastest way to make money from this asset is through third-party partnerships.

In recent months, management has repeatedly pointed to such opportunities during conference calls and investor conferences, and today's earnings call seemed to bring even greater intensity to this subject. It actually sounded like there is some concrete near-term opportunity in sight, with a potential announcement not too far away.

Since nobody really knows how big such an announcement would be, which figures it would involve and how it would impact the stock's fundamentals, some short covering is probably the prudent thing to do.

Conclusions

While Sirius XM's effective turnaround is still not there – the market would need to see increasing subscriber numbers for a couple of quarters – investors are probably seeing that subscriber dynamics are not the only and maybe not even the most important thing to watch here.

As I explained in my recent article on Berkshire's likely endgame, if SIRI doesn't deteriorate rapidly, this investment can still deliver good results. It is a classic value investment: The spectrum assets, its real estate in most of the U.S. car fleet, its low-churn subscriber base, and, last but not least, its robust FCF generation coupled with buybacks can yield decent investment results even with a slowly declining subscriber base.

The most recent quarter has given some substance to that theory, and highlighted the possibility that (1) subscribers might even grow again, while (2) the company might surprise with some unexpected spectrum-related capital inflow and/or moat-enhancing partnership.

This is why the stock rallied.

data.title: How Rare Earths Became The Next Trade War Weapon
data.description:
By Ewa Manthey

The US remains heavily dependent on China for rare earths, which are essential to defence, clean energy, and high-tech manufacturing. While the delay eases immediate pressure on industries reliant on rare earths, it should prompt a renewed focus on building alternative supply routes – from developing domestic mining, processing and refining capacity to strengthening partnerships with allied producers.

The trade-truce buys time, but lasting security will depend on reducing exposure to China’s dominance in this critical sector.

Why are rare earths critical?

Rare earth elements (REEs) - a group of 17 chemically related elements including neodymium, dysprosium, and terbium – are essential to the functioning of modern economies. Rare earths are key to everything from smartphones and wind turbines to EV motors and advanced military systems.

The 17 rare earth elements are typically grouped into light REEs (LREEs), including lanthanum, cerium, neodymium, praseodymium, which are used in magnets, batteries and catalysts, and heavy REEs (HREEs), which include dysprosium, terbium, yttrium – they are rarer, used in high-performance magnets, lasers, and alloys.

Rare earths in everyday technology

Source: ING Research

Rare earths are not actually rare, geologically speaking. For example, cerium is more abundant than copper. But although REEs are abundant in the Earth’s crust, they are rarely found in concentrations suitable for economic extraction. Their chemical similarity makes separation complex and environmentally challenging.

China dominates mined production of rare earths

Source: USGS, ING Research

And it’s home to almost half the world’s reserves of rare earths

Source: USGS, ING Research

China’s dominance is decades in the making

The US was the world’s top producer of rare earths until the 1980s, before China’s dominance rose due to lower costs and government support for its rare earths industry.

China’s dominance didn’t happen overnight. Beginning in the 1980s, Beijing identified rare earths as a strategic industry, supporting development through subsidies, financing, favourable regulation and export controls.

By the 1990s, China had become the world’s leading producer. Deng Xiaoping famously said in 1992: “The Middle East has its oil; China has rare earths”.

Today, China accounts for roughly 70% of global REE mine output, 90% of refining, and over 90% of magnet production.

Supply chain bottleneck

The rare earth supply chain is highly concentrated. Deposits exist outside of China, notably in Brazil, the US, and Australia, but many rely on Chinese refiners. It is refining capacity, rather than mineral wealth, that is the source of vulnerability.

Australia’s Lynas Rare Earths (OTCPK:LYSCF) (OTCPK:LYSDY) is the world’s largest supplier of rare earths outside of China; it relies on Malaysia for part of its refining.

Only two refineries exist outside China: one in the US and one in Malaysia.

Global rare earths refined supply by region

Source: BNEF, ING Research

Scaling up remains slow due to high costs, technical complexity, and long permitting deadlines. Building a new mine can take eight to ten years, while building a new refinery takes about five.

Building mines, refineries, and processing plants in places like Australia, the US, and Europe also costs more because of higher capital needs, stricter environmental rules, and pricier labour and energy than in China.

Even if the planned refineries outside China come online by 2030, total capacity will just be half of China’s 2024 supply (according to BNEF data).

But without independent refining capacity, Western producers remain dependent on China.

Estimated rare earths refinery capacity growth outside of China

Source: BNEF, ING Research

How has Beijing used rare earths as a weapon in the trade war?

China has a history of using its dominance in the supply of rare earths as a pressure tool.

China’s grip on the rare earths market became apparent in 2010 when it blocked exports to Japan for two months over a territorial dispute. The US, the European Union and Japan eventually forced Beijing to overturn the measures via the World Trade Organisation. The incident spurred Japan’s efforts to reduce its reliance on China. Japan’s dependence on China’s rare earths dropped from around 90% at the time of the incident to around 60% today.

This year saw a significant escalation of China’s rare earth restrictions as Beijing used its dominance over the critical materials to pressure the US administration.

In April, in response to escalating trade tensions, including US tariffs, Beijing imposed export restrictions on seven rare earths and permanent magnets, with companies needing to secure special licenses to send these materials overseas. The curbs included some heavy rare earths, which are almost exclusively produced by China. This was the first time China has placed rare earth magnets on the export control list.

The global automotive industry was among the sectors significantly affected by China’s export controls on rare earth magnets. Ford Motor temporarily shut a Chicago factory in May after running short of rare earth components. In the European Union, companies also reported several production stoppages.

Then, October saw sweeping new restrictions with Beijing outlining plans to expand curbs, including requiring overseas exporters of items that contain even small amounts of certain rare earths sourced from China to have an export license. It also subjected technology and equipment related to rare earths processing and magnets to export controls. These measures will now be suspended for a year. The original restrictions announced in April, targeting seven heavy rare earths, weren’t addressed in the statement following this week's meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

The US accounted for 10% of China’s total rare earth exports in 2024, but restrictions have led to a 12% drop in shipments to the US from the first to the third quarter of 2025.

China total rare earth’s exports volume by region

Source: China General Customs Administration, BNEF, ING Research

Magnets drive China’s rare earths exports

Source: China’s General Administration of Customs, ING Research

How will the US boost production of rare earths?

MP Materials operates the only American rare earths mine – Mountain Pass in California’s Mojave Desert, reopened in 2018, and once the world’s top supplier before production shifted to China. It received a $400 million investment from the Pentagon in July, which helped the company fund a new magnets plant in a deal that came with guaranteed purchases at minimum prices.

Trump is also looking beyond the US for rare earths supplies.

Earlier this month, the US and Australia agreed to jointly invest in Australian mines and processing projects. Both countries also pledged to protect their domestic markets from “unfair trade practices”, using trade measures like floor prices. Australia ranks fourth in rare earth reserves. Still, most projects are several years away from becoming operational.

The US President has also sealed a series of deals on his Asia trip to secure rare earth supplies, including deals with Japan, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia.

The deal with Japan involves the two sides agreeing to boost the supply and production of rare earths, including plans for coordinated investment and stockpiling of rare earths. Meanwhile, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia all agreed to increase US access to rare earths and export rules that would favour American buyers over Chinese companies. These include promises that they will not block shipments to the US. They would also encourage local processing and investment by non-Chinese firms.

These deals mark progress towards more diversified supply chains of rare earths, marking a shift in approach, increasing support and involvement from the state.

Rising demand adds urgency

The rise in demand from EVs, renewable energy, and defence adds urgency to the market. The International Energy Agency (IEA) projects strong growth in rare earth demand driven by clean energy technologies. EVs are expected to lead, with a compound annual growth rate of 17.2% from 2024 to 2030, followed by wind turbines at 7.5%. Overall, rare earth demand is forecast to grow at 5.1% annually during this period. Other end uses include defence, mobile phones, displays, medical imaging, speakers, headphones, control rods in nuclear reactors and catalysts.

Rare earth demand is rising

Source: IEA, ING Research

Loosening China’s grip on rare earths won’t be easy

The deal between Trump and Xi should not give policymakers a false sense of security. Instead, it must serve as a reminder that the United States urgently needs to accelerate efforts to build a supply chain for critical minerals and magnets that does not depend on China. Beijing’s dominance means it can tighten export restrictions at any time.

In the near term, China will likely maintain its edge, thanks to technical expertise, low costs, and an extensive supply network. But rare earth supply chains must diversify. International cooperation and investment are essential first steps.

Breaking Beijing’s grip on rare earths will be slow and expensive, but the payoff is strategic independence. Export controls that give China leverage today will ultimately spur global efforts to develop non-Chinese supply chains. The more the world invests in onshoring and alternative suppliers, the less control China will wield in the long run.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

Original Post

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: UNH - 3 Reasons Not To Buy After 'Beat & Raise'
data.description:
UnitedHealth (UNH) has become a favorite stock for value investors in 2025, as the share price dropped dramatically due to investor concerns about margins and growth potential.

From a low of around $240 in August, the share price has risen nicely to $355 as I write this update, close to a 50% gain. This still leaves a large gap to recover previous highs of over $600. The hope of mean reversion continues to attract a lot of interest from value investors.

UNH reported third quarter earnings on October 28, beating analyst expectations on key metrics, and raising guidance. On the surface, this looks like a great result, however the beat and the raise were modest. There remain three areas of concern to me.

Firstly, the underwriting performance of the risk business, second, the performance and outlook for Optum Health, and finally, the valuation.

In my mind, these are more significant than the modest beats. First, let's recap the earnings and then look into the longer term risks for United Health.

Q3 Earnings

There are three green highlights in the numbers, compared to consensus.

Adjusted earnings per share were $2.92, which beat consensus by $0.11, or around 4%. This is clearly a positive however it's important to bear in mind that this is on the back of large earnings misses, and reduced consensus. Analysts would have been conservative in setting the outlook after Q2. The average reduction from prior estimates is around 40% over the coming three years.

Revenues were up 12%, year on year, beating estimates by $104m, which while a large number, is a tiny fraction of the expected $112bn.

This is not driven by organic growth in the business, but more by increased premiums. The company provides good detail in the change in number of customers served, which as you can see, shows only very modest growth overall.

As we know from the increased medical cost ratio, the premiums are not generating higher margins. In fact, net margins are down 3.9% year on year to just 2.1%.

The good news here is that the medical care ratio - or MCR, for the quarter came in as expected at 89.9%, which was a re-cast estimate from Q2. After an increase in the MCR from competitor Molina Healthcare (MOH), this was encouraging.

Finally, guidance was raised, with adjusted EPS guidance increased from $16 to $16.25, up about 1.5% from the Q2 guidance. Again, it's important to remember that UNH first withdrew guidance, then dramatically reduced their 2025 guidance. A nominal raise like this seems to me to be more of a sweetener for investors than a material upgrade.

The earnings have been well covered by S.A. authors, with an overwhelming 'Buy' bias. Under the radar however, there is some cooling of enthusiasm from several.

The broader market seems lukewarm - shares of UNH have dropped by 3.4% at the time of writing.

Three Reasons Not To Buy Here

There are three areas of concern to me that keep me cautious.

Medical Care Ratio Outlook

As has been widely discussed, the key challenge with the sector has been margin pressure arising from an increase in the cost of patient care, as represented by the MCR key performance indicator.

There are two sides to this coin, the premium rates charged, and the cost of care.

As I discussed in detail here, rates are tightly regulated in most of the risk insurance products offered by United.

Much of the positive expectation and outlook for United, and peers in the sector, hinges around re-pricing. The assumption is that rates can be increased enough to restore historical margins.

I was hoping that United, as the market leader, would provide details of the pricing adjustments for 2026 that they have been able to achieve.

There was a fair amount of discussion on the earnings call.

Management discussed the process of rate increases segment by segment.

Medicare Advantage - cost inflation is trending at 7.5%, and is expected to trend to 10% in 2026. Other Medicare segments are viewed consistently.

Commercial Insurance repricing is around 60% complete for 2026. Margins are expected to recover through 2026 with a return to historical margins only in 2027.

ACA markets are more challenging. Rate re-filings are reported to exceed 25%, however these seem not to be broadly accepted by the states. In response, the company expects to reduce ACA membership by 2/3 of current levels, a massive market share reduction.

Medicaid was left until last. Here only half of the rates to be effective January 1st have been agreed. Half remain open. United expects 2025 to be broadly breakeven for Medicaid, and 2026 to be negative by around 1.5%.

In terms of margin outlook, for the risk business, the target remains a return to 7-9% margins. However, expectations are that 2026 will miss the bottom end of that range by 1.5%.

All in all, a rational approach to setting medical cost inflation trends. The expectation however is for cost trends to increase up to 10% year on year, up from around 7.5%. That's a rapid pace of change with increasing momentum. I see a material risk that the trend could continue to accelerate, and the 10% undershoots.

Secondly, a big driver has been benefit utilisation levels. Management provided little insight into expectations here. My concern is that significant increases in pricing will drive away healthier members, who submit fewer claims, leaving the residual risk pool overweighted to the 'frequent flyers' who use benefits more. An increase in net utilisation levels could result in further pressure on the MCR even if rates can rise faster than medical inflation trends.

Thirdly, pricing. Other than quoting a big number of 25% increases in rate re-filings there was little data available of the actual level of rate increases being achieved in the segments.

I see a material risk to the margin expectations for 2026. The outlook for 2027 and beyond indicated reversion to historical margins, but any margin under-performance in 2026 is likely to flow into the outer years.

Optum

Optum Health is undergoing a massive turnaround in the Value Based Care segment. Optum Rx CEO Patrick Conway was pretty straightforward in outlining the mistakes made here, which are all related to growing too aggressively. This stretched across the provider network and the product range offered, and the rapid growth created operational and integration issues.

Conway described a significant repositioning here, with a reduction of the partnership footprint to seek restored profitability.

The application of a new risk scoring and payment regulatory mechanism called v28 caused significant margin erosion, and Optum is having to renegotiate partner contracts to mitigate this.

The targets for margin improvement are significant. Current margins are expected to be under 3%, pulled down by value based care margins of less than 1%. Medicare funding cuts are identified as a headwind.

The long term margin targets for the business are for margins to improve to 6-8%

Similarly, the fee based Optum business has been underperforming, and significant work is being done here to turn the business around.

A bright spot is in Optum Insights, where AI applications are hoped to generate significant future revenue streams and profitable growth. The company continues to invest here, but there were few concrete details of progress.

Finally, Optum Rx, the PBM, has been performing well, with solid margins and growth. No mention was made of the DOJ probe into Optum Rx billing practices, which I found disappointing. This could have the potential to create headwinds for Optum Rx if the findings are negative, or create the need for changes in the operating model.

The PBM sector has been the subject of criticism from the current administration, with President Trump referring to the sector as, "The horrible middleman that makes more money, frankly, than the drug companies, and they don't do anything except they're a middleman," as reported by Reuters.

As this article from 'pharmaforum' discusses, legislation targeting PBM margins is included in the upcoming legislative docket, drawing strong lobbying efforts from the PBM industry. The legislation seeks to squeeze margins by changing the rules on 'spread pricing' whereby PBMs add margins on drug costs.

These are just a couple of examples of the pressure currently facing PBMs. However, there seems to be little discussion or awareness of the risk to growth and margins in the PBM sector.

So, in one way or another, most of the segments of Optum are either managing turnarounds, or facing risks. I'd like to see more discussion of these, evidence of progress, and clarity on potential impacts before having full confidence in the Optum business potential.

Valuation

Despite the recent under-performance, and ongoing challenges to the business, in my view, United is not cheap.

The current price is close to 22x 2025 expected earnings, and 20x 2026 estimates.

That puts the company priced pretty much where it has been for the last decade to 2024.

During which time the company was able to consistently grow earnings per share.

And United trades at a massive premium to its biggest competitors Elevance (ELV) and Centene (CNC), while facing many of the same risks and opportunities.

Yes, there is certainly a quality premium discussion to be had, however, the magnitude here is in my view too rich.

Conclusion & My Strategy

While the earnings for Q3 represented a start on a return to performance consistency, and beat expectations, the beat was modest. It is certainly comforting that management has raised guidance, and their long term outlook is positive.

However, that outlook requires a significant turnaround in several areas, while there remains a significant threat from macro and political headwinds.

The share price has recovered significantly from lows, and in my view, while further upside is possible, the current valuation is stretched. I rate UNH as a Hold.

In my own portfolio, I took a long position around $300, hedging by selling OTM calls. My shares were called away for $330, for a total return of around 25% including call premiums. I am now short Nov 11th $320 puts.

data.title: Microsoft Stock Dips As $35B AI Spending Plan Sparks Margin Concerns Despite Azure Strength
data.description:
By Parshwa Turakhiya

​Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) shares fell nearly 4% in extended trading after the company disclosed record capital expenditure of $35 billion in its fiscal first quarter, well above Wall Street expectations. Management warned that spending would stay elevated through the year as it expands AI and cloud infrastructure.

While the move underscores Microsoft’s long-term ambition to dominate artificial intelligence, investors reacted cautiously to the near-term cost pressure, highlighting the delicate balance between growth and profitability.

Technical setup signals pause after major rally

The daily chart shows Microsoft consolidating after a sharp rally earlier this year that pushed shares to $554.83. The stock has now retraced toward the $541 zone, coinciding with the 0.786 Fibonacci retracement and immediate resistance-turned-support. The 20-day EMA at $522.57 and 50-day EMA at $515.12 sit just below current levels, forming critical near-term floors. A decisive break under this cluster could expose the 100-day EMA at $500.47, while the 200-day EMA at $475.20 anchors the broader uptrend.

Microsoft stock price dynamics (Source: TradingView)

Price action remains within a rising channel structure, signaling that the long-term bullish pattern of higher highs and higher lows is intact. However, momentum indicators show early signs of fatigue. The RSI is hovering at 72, suggesting overbought conditions that often precede consolidation phases. Unless the stock reclaims $555 resistance and sustains above it, the probability of further sideways action or a mild pullback remains high.

Azure strength steadies investor confidence

Despite the headline spending shock, Azure cloud performance delivered an upside surprise. The division grew 40% year-over-year in the July–September quarter, beating estimates of 38.4%. The company guided for 37% growth in the current quarter, signaling sustained demand. CFO Amy Hood emphasized that capacity limitations had capped stronger growth, implying the elevated capital expenditure is aimed at eliminating those bottlenecks.

The spending surge mirrors a broader pattern across Big Tech as firms race to expand AI infrastructure. Alphabet and Meta also warned of rising costs tied to data center buildouts and AI deployment. While these investments strengthen long-term competitive positions, they are likely to pressure margins through the near term.

Revenue guidance between $79.5 billion and $80.6 billion for the current quarter met expectations, maintaining confidence in Microsoft’s ability to generate consistent top-line growth. Analysts note that the company’s diverse business lines — spanning Azure, Office 365, and gaming — continue to provide stability despite increased capital intensity.

Outlook: Balancing cost and cloud growth

For investors, the trade-off is clear: accept near-term margin compression in exchange for leadership in AI infrastructure. The chart structure suggests consolidation, with $515–$522 as the zone to watch for trend confirmation. Holding above this range keeps bullish bias intact, while a slip toward $500 could shift momentum defensively. On the upside, reclaiming $555 opens the door to a retest of the 1.618 Fibonacci extension near $593.

As previously discussed, Microsoft’s long-term thesis remains tied to its cloud and AI dominance. The short-term pressure on margins may weigh on sentiment, but as Azure growth accelerates and new AI tools gain traction, the company’s ability to balance cost discipline with innovation will determine whether the recent pullback evolves into a buying opportunity or signals a deeper correction.

This material may contain third-party opinions; none of the data and information on this webpage constitutes investment advice according to our Disclaimer. While we adhere to strict Editorial Integrity, this post may contain references to products from our partners.

Original Post

data.title: Karat Packaging: Small Cap Growth Opportunity
data.description:
Who is Karat Packaging?

Karat Packaging (KRT) is a holding company. It’s major subsidiary, Lollicup USA Inc is a specialty distributor and manufacturer of single use disposable products mainly for the restaurant and foodservices industry. There are several ‘sub-categories’ which encompass a wide range of products and services.

Karat is the major brand, and it provides high quality disposable food packaging, containers, tableware, cups, lids, cutlery, and straws.

Karat Earth takes Karat to the next level by focusing on eco-friendly products, allowing customers who are environmentally conscious to buy and use sustainable and recyclable or compostable products.

Tea Zone delivers premium tea and syrup solutions to the bubble tea industry.

Total Clean offers a full range of janitorial products as well as general and warehouse supplies.

Why now

A couple of years ago the company pivoted to a more asset light model which saw the majority of revenue shift from manufacturing to distribution. Low freight costs and competitively priced products were a great offset against high local costs (particularly labor).

Local Manufacturing then dropped from roughly 20% of sales to 11% currently, however they have maintained select US manufacturing capability to enable agility & flexibility and to help with short lead times and urgent orders.

As per a recent presentation in September 2025 ecofriendly products have risen to 33.6% of sales in 2024. This is the niche which the company is choosing to focus on, and I’d expect a lot of effort to be directed to these lines of business going forward. Tariffs have had a relatively benign impact on the business as their products are sourced from lower Tariff countries like Taiwan (tariff 10%) and Vietnam (tariff 20%) with ‘just’ 10% of sourcing from China at the time of writing.

This niche has some major tailwinds going for it, firstly Government is proposing via the ‘farewell to foam act’ to ban the use of Styrofoam on a phase out basis by 2028. (11 states have pre-empted this by already issuing bans). Another tailwind is the ongoing ESG drive by both corporates and consumers as ‘doing the right thing’ and a drive to a better, healthier more sustainable ‘lifestyle’ becomes more common place globally.

According to ‘Towards Packaging’ the size of the sustainable packaging market is set to reach $73.81bn by 2034 in the USA, growing at a rate of 4.15% per annum with food and beverage expected to consume the largest share of the spend (41.4%). Polaris research see the global food service disposables market growing at 4.6% annually to reach a value of $98.5bn by 2034.

Eco conscious consumers are choosing to support companies and brands which focus on this and its creating customer loyalty. A brand's product packaging is a competitive advantage too, it’s functional, key to maintaining freshness and appearance & it’s a potential differentiator in a competitive market. The packaging itself can of course also be used for advertising and promotion. Some great companies are already using their products in the US FMCG space.

The customer base has broadened too. ‘Pure’ distribution allows the company to serve national and regional peers. Products are delivered across the US using companies which are far larger and more established than themselves. In fact, it could be said that it’s turned some competitors into customers.

FMCG and Distributors (which includes Supermarkets) account for 78.1% of Net Sales, the number of accounts in this sector have grown by over 10x from 2020 through 2024, whilst revenue has grown by 33%.

Online sales either directly or via platforms such as Amazon, Walmart, eBay and TikTok are growing even faster (and with higher margins) at 111% over the same period. These now account for 17% of Net Sales.

Flavors and syrups for the bubble tea market make up the balance at 4.9% of Net Sales.

This broad and diverse cohort of customers in varying industries has helped reduce concentration risk and now no single client accounts for more than 10% of revenue.

Covid provided a boom for the industry with growth of around 40% in sales over the 2020-2022 period. Since then, however, it’s been fairly stagnant as pull forward demand has been absorbed by a normalized market, however I think we’re poised to see growth start picking up again.

Being ‘on trend’ with the shift to clean and green, a new opportunity has opened up for the company and they have developed an important niche as a scaled leading player in the eco-friendly foodservice packaging space.

By avoiding mass commodity supply and focusing on high mix, fast turnaround, branded and specialty packaging instead the company has managed to grind out ever better margins and earnings and even better they have gone from being cash flow negative as recently as 2021 to generating around $50m in free cash flow over the last 12 months.

Another compelling point in my view is the fact that insiders own a massive amount of stock, in fact over 57% of the company sits with the founders and other staff. This is true alignment in my book. There is an incentive to grow the business over time, to keep paying a hefty dividend and to ensure that wealth is protected. As shareholders, I’d like to think that our interests would be aligned with those of the founders who in turn would manage their (and our wealth) with care and integrity. On top of this both founders earn very modest salaries and no additional stock options as part of their compensation structure. This probably explains why such a large dividend is paid and is certainly further incentive to increase profits to increase the company’s value and future dividend pay outs.

Packaging has always been fiercely competitive with a slew of companies fighting for share in what is generally a slow-growing low-margin market. This is why it’s important to try and disrupt or shake the market up if you’re small and up and coming. By using new technologies and being nimble smaller players can pivot quickly to changing circumstances and market dynamics.

This is where the eco-friendly, higher margin, niche stands to shine. These products made up about a third of net sales last year and the company sees further room for expansion and growth. This is primarily because of two levers, firstly a small starting base and secondly as alluded to above, government mandates that propose to ban certain materials that have been commonly used in the past. The company aims to fill gaps in product lines to get restaurant and food service customers what they need, quickly and efficiently.

No matter who you consider as a competitor KRT is small. With Revenue of $ 422.6m in 2024 and a market cap of $ 500m this is not a large company. However, therein lies the opportunity in my view. Karat is still ‘young’ with a lot of growth potential ahead of it, here’s my thinking:

Consensus forecasts through 2027 are calling for Revenue growth of roughly 8% per annum with EPS growth of 12%. Against market growth of 4% this is telling me they’re slowly gaining share and with sales of $422m (in a market forecast to be worth around $74bn in 2034) there is a lot of share to be had. Just a 1% market share implies sales of $740m and 75% growth from here for example.

VALUATION

Looking at it from a DCF perspective. Extrapolating 12% earnings growth over the next three years (these are consensus numbers) and then dropping them down to 4% after that to line the company up with market growth of 4.15% (the Towards Packaging figure above) would imply that they gain a small amount of market share up until 2027 and then stagnate after that. Using the average return of the S&P500 over the long term (10%) as the discount rate, we get a fair value of $31.90.

If I pivot over to a dividend discount model and assume that the dividend grows in line with long term earnings, as alluded to above (4%) and using its calculated COE based on a dividend capitalisation model, we come out at $ 29.19.

From a PE perspective assuming 15x 2027 forecast earnings, (a 10% discount to today’s multiple) we’d get to $ 31.50.

Blending the 3 together gives us a value of $ 30.86. Compared to a current share price of $24.59 this would imply upside up to $31.00 or 26%. With a current dividend yield of 7.3% your total return potential could be in the 30's.

RISKS

As with any investment there are always risks to consider. Over and above the normal market and economic risk that any company faces daily, one also needs to consider the fact that this is a small company, it competes in a low moat, low cost and very competitive industry. The restaurant industry in particular is cut throat and cost conscious. Packaging is a commodity and unless you can demonstrate real value add, lowest price wins.

Large founder skin in the game is always a big positive in my world, however in this instance the ownership structure is arguably more complex than it needs to be. There are also several related party transactions that could make some potential investors uncomfortable. For example, the CEO’s brother owns one of the companies’ overseas suppliers and roughly 13% of products sold came from this company. (page 68, point 17 of the 10-k)

On the dividend, last year they paid more than they earned with the difference supported by free cash flow. This is unsustainable and not what I like to see. Slow or no dividend growth is therefore possible going forward as they grow into the dividend. I see a lower dividend as unlikely unless forced as founder compensation is closely tied to it.

CONCLUSION

Sometimes solid investment opportunities come in different guises. Most of us look for glamourous industries and companies where most of the buzz is. Today for example its things like AI, reshoring and energy transition with others like obesity drugs and crypto still up there and top of mind for many.

But what if you took a few steps to the left or right of these themes and looked for companies that help facilitate these trends and provide solutions for customers at the same time? Oftentimes those sweet spots are ignored or not even considered because they’re so ‘unromantic’ or not in vogue. Rarely for example will you see a social media influencer touting the need for a good plumber or high-quality toilet paper. Nobody cares until you need it right!

In my opinion Karat packaging fits into this mold. It provides essential and needed products to its customers and its customers’ customers, helping them meet their needs in a green and eco friendly manner.

I bet you’ve never really thought about how your takeaway meal is packaged or presented to you. As long as it arrives on time and looks appealing you’re happy.

We all (myself included) take for granted the ‘other’ things that restaurants of all sizes provide whether you eat in or take out. Napkins, straws, take out containers, cups and even cutlery are items that are just ‘there’ yet without them our meal experience would just not be the same.

Being ‘on trend’ with the shift to clean and green, a new opportunity has opened up for the company and they have developed an important niche as a leading player in the eco-friendly foodservice packaging space which I think deserves an investment.

With potential returns in the 30% range, this stock is finding a place in my growth portfolio with a modest allocation to begin with. I rate Karat Packaging (KRT) as a Buy for more risk tolerant investors.

data.title: EMXC: Emerging Markets Exposure Without China Tariff Risk
data.description:
Introduction

So far in 2025, the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ex China ETF (EMXC) has significantly outperformed the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY), delivering a total return of ~33%:

This comes as China has been a key target for President Trump's tariff policy, with the country facing a 47% tariff even after the latest 10% reduction. In this context, I believe EMXC offers a convenient way for investors to benefit from strong emerging markets GDP growth without the risk of on and off China tariffs for the remainder of President Trump's term in office.

I rank EMXC a Buy, expecting its outperformance relative to the SPY to continue in 2026, driven by:

  • A trailing earnings yield of about 5.42%, almost 2% higher than the S&P 500.
  • 2026 GDP growth of 3.16% for EMXC countries, again some 1% higher than the projected growth rate in the United States.
  • A well-covered dividend yield of 2.36%, with the potential for 7-8% dividend growth in 2026.

In this article, I will expand on these points and discuss risks related to the investment case.

ETF Overview

You can access all EMXC results on the iShares website here. EMXC invests in large and mid-cap emerging market equities outside China. The largest allocation is to Taiwan (28.76% of ETF assets), indicating you still have the risk of tensions between Taiwan and China escalating. India is the second largest weight, at 21.77%, followed by South Korea at 17.32%:

From a sector perspective, the Information Technology sector accounts for 35.12% of assets, followed by Financials at 24.14%, Industrials at 7.86% and Materials at 7.30%:

On the one hand, this sector allocation makes EMXC a key beneficiary of AI/automation growth. On the other hand, the ETF's performance is also dependent on strong economic growth, with cyclical sectors such as financials, industrials, materials and consumer discretionary accounting for 45.11% of assets.

The ETF's expense ratio stands at 0.25%. This is marginally above the 0.1-0.2% range I find appealing for a long-term passive holding. What is more, while the ETF invests in some 653 individual companies, exposure to the top two holdings alone accounts for 21.16% of ETF assets:

As such, investors looking to save on fees may consider the rationale of investing directly in the two largest holdings - Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM) and Samsung Electronics (OTCPK:SSNLF).

Current Valuation

I estimate EMXC holdings currently trade at 18.45x their trailing P/E multiple, or an earnings yield of about 5.42%. Given the elevated information technology allocation, I view EMXC as quite comparable to the S&P 500, notwithstanding a smaller financial sector allocation in the leading U.S. benchmark.

I calculate that the S&P 500 currently trades at 29.1x its trailing earnings, or an earnings yield of 3.44%. Hence we can say that the current valuation suggests that S&P 500 earnings would have to grow almost 2% faster in perpetuity just to make up for higher starting valuations relative to EMXC, something I see as unsustainable over the long term.

GDP Growth Outlook

While GDP growth is an imperfect proxy for earnings growth, for ETFs with a diverse country allocation I find GDP growth to be a good starting point when evaluating future earnings growth prospects.

In the table below, I have estimated the country-weighted EMXC GDP growth outlook for 2026 using the IMF's October 2025 World Economic Outlook:

Country Weight GDP growth 2026
Taiwan 28.76% 2.1%
India 21.77% 6.2%
South Korea 17.32% 1.8%
Brazil 5.84% 1.9%
South Africa 4.83% 1.2%
Saudi Arabia 4.50% 4%
Mexico 2.70% 1.5%
United Arab Emirates 2.07% 5%
Malaysia 1.61% 4%
Indonesia 1.57% 4.9%
Poland 1.48% 3.1%
Thailand 1.44% 1.6%
Other/cash 6.13% Not relevant
Total 100% 3.16%

Source: Author calculations

My calculations show that country-weighted GDP growth for EMXC should amount to about 3.16% in 2026, with the ETF benefiting from its large allocation to India which is forecast to deliver GDP growth of 6.2% next year.

The IMF projects U.S. GDP growth at 2.1% next year, roughly 1% below my weighted average estimate for EMXC. As such, while it is always possible that earnings growth deviates somewhat from GDP growth, I think that EMXC will deliver earnings growth at least on par, if not better, than the S&P 500.

Dividend Appeal

EMXC offers a current dividend yield of 2.36%, indicating a payout ratio of about 0.48 when we factor in the ETF's expense ratio of 0.25%. As such, I view the current dividend as sustainable, with my estimates showing that dividends should increase by 7-8% in 2026, marginally below the 9.88% annual increase over the past three years:

My dividend growth outlook is driven by retained earnings, solid GDP growth, and inflation somewhat above 2% in emerging markets. Amid ongoing Fed rate cuts, I view EMXC as an ideal ETF for investors focused on dividend growth.

EMXC Rating

Even after the strong year-to-date outperformance, EMXC holdings offer a trailing earnings yield some 2% higher than the S&P 500. GDP growth projections for 2026 remain favorable, with EMXC countries likely to deliver GDP growth roughly 1% stronger than the United States.

As discussed in the Dividend Appeal section, the ETF also offers a dividend yield that is double that of the cheapest S&P 500-tracking options such as the Vanguard S&P 500 ETF (VOO), with VOO currently offering a paltry 1.11% dividend yield. I also believe that EMXC dividend growth will exceed that of the S&P 500 going forward.

As such, I think that EMXC will continue to outperform the S&P 500 in 2026, ranking the ETF with a Buy rating.

Risks

Investing in emerging markets comes with elevated risks compared to the more established U.S. capital market. Firstly, while EMXC is traded in USD, it represents an implicit short USD bet since the ETF invests in companies traded in local currencies such as the Taiwan dollar and Indian rupee. As such, investors not comfortable with currency risk should avoid emerging market ETFs such as EMXC.

Secondly, there is no guarantee that strong GDP growth will translate into robust earnings growth for EMXC holdings. For emerging markets, the link between GDP growth and corporate earnings growth may not be as strong, since capital markets are not as developed as those in the United States.

Last but certainly not least in terms of importance, with 35.12% of ETF assets allocated to the information technology sector, EMXC is particularly exposed to the risk of AI/automation growth falling short of expectations. Likewise the ETF's 45.11% allocation to cyclical sectors exposes EMXC to losses should GDP growth fall short of expectations.

Conclusion

China tariff tensions have been a key point of contention so far in 2025, culminating in the April 2025 market selloff. While recent headlines suggest the risk of a full-blown trade war is receding, the rivalry between the United States and China will likely be a defining feature this century as the two super powers battle for influence in economic affairs.

Against this backdrop, investors can mitigate China-related risks and at the same time benefit from superb emerging markets growth by investing in EMXC. The ETF's holdings currently offer an earnings yield some 2% higher than the S&P 500, while GDP growth is likely to be roughly 1% higher than that of the United States.

Coupled with a higher dividend yield and better dividend growth prospects, I believe this should result in continued outperformance of EMXC relative to the S&P 500 in 2026, ranking EMXC a Buy.

Key risks in the investment case include currency risk, the imperfect link between GDP expansion and earnings growth, and the ETF's outsized exposure to cyclical sectors and the AI/automation growth theme.

Thank you for reading.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: S&P 500 Steadies As Fed Caution And Mixed Earnings Test Rally Strength
data.description:
By Parshwa Turakhiya

​The S&P 500 (SP500) closed near 6,890 on Wednesday, just shy of the 6,900 mark, as investors navigated a volatile session shaped by mixed corporate earnings and cautious commentary from the Federal Reserve. Futures for the index and Nasdaq were steady, while Dow Jones futures slipped on profit-taking in industrials.

The tone across markets reflected hesitation ahead of major earnings releases from Apple and Amazon, and uncertainty over the Fed’s next policy move.

Technical picture shows a wedge formation near resistance

Technically, the S&P 500 remains within a rising channel that has defined the uptrend since May. Price action is now testing the upper boundary near 6,920, a level that has repeatedly capped previous breakout attempts. The 20-day EMA at 6,739 serves as immediate support, followed by the 50-day EMA near 6,622—both aligning with the channel’s midline and marking critical buffers against short-term corrections.

S&P 500 price dynamics (Source: TradingView)

A decisive breakout above 6,920 could propel the index toward the symbolic 7,000 threshold, while a drop below 6,740–6,620 would risk triggering a deeper pullback toward 6,445, where the 100-day EMA and prior demand zone converge. The RSI remains elevated but not extreme, suggesting momentum is intact though vulnerable to fatigue if fresh catalysts fail to emerge.

Earnings volatility and Fed tone shape sentiment

The market’s tone was dominated by post-earnings swings in mega-cap stocks. Microsoft slipped 2% after disclosing a $3.1 billion charge linked to its OpenAI investment, while Meta plunged nearly 9% due to a $15.93 billion expense tied to President Trump’s “One Big Beautiful Bill” Act. In contrast, Alphabet rallied 8% on strong cloud and ad revenue growth, helping offset weakness in other sectors. Eli Lilly added 3.5% after raising full-year guidance, underscoring the continued rotation between growth and defensive names.

Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s remarks at the post-meeting conference added a layer of caution. While the Fed delivered a 25-basis-point rate cut earlier this week, Powell emphasized that another cut in December was “not a foregone conclusion,” a statement that tempered risk appetite and nudged Treasury yields slightly higher. For equities already priced near record valuations, Powell’s language reinforced that monetary policy may not remain as supportive as markets anticipate.

Macro backdrop offers mild relief

Geopolitical developments provided a modest tailwind. The Trump–Xi summit concluded with a partial trade truce that included a 10% reduction in U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports, bringing the overall rate to 47%.

In return, China agreed to curb fentanyl exports and expand purchases of American agricultural goods. While the deal lacked major breakthroughs, it helped ease global risk sentiment by lowering trade-related uncertainty at the margins.

Outlook: Bulls hold control but watch key levels

The S&P 500 continues to trade within a well-defined bullish structure, though near-term gains may be harder to sustain as earnings and Fed policy expectations collide. Immediate resistance sits at 6,920, followed by the 7,000 level, while key supports remain at 6,740 and 6,620.

As previously discussed, the index’s broader trend remains upward, supported by robust earnings in parts of the tech and healthcare sectors. However, with monetary policy tightening expectations in flux and investor positioning stretched, traders should brace for volatility around upcoming earnings reports and macro data releases. The next few sessions will determine whether the S&P 500 can push through to new highs or settle into consolidation before year-end.

This material may contain third-party opinions; none of the data and information on this webpage constitutes investment advice according to our Disclaimer. While we adhere to strict Editorial Integrity, this post may contain references to products from our partners.

Original Post

data.title: Alphabet: For The First Time In Three Years, My Rating Is Not A Buy (Downgrade)
data.description:
One of the companies I appreciate the most, but I'm not buying now

Over the last three years I have published 9 articles on Alphabet Inc. aka Google (GOOG), and each one presented a Buy/Strong Buy rating. I have always believed in this company’s potential and I invested as much as possible up until few months ago. I still remember when the market was scared about ChatGPT replacing Alphabet’s core business, something that in hindsight proved totally wrong. By the way, now Gemini has 650 million monthly active users.

As a shareholder, I couldn’t be more satisfied by the recent Q3 2025 results, but the price per share is getting a parabolic slope, something that makes me wary.

Of course, as I’ll show you, fundamentals improved a lot and I won’t sell a single share, but is $300 per share a good level to start a position? That is the main question of the article.

Q3 2025 was a terrific quarter

To understand why Q3 2025 was a terrific quarter we just need to look at this slide.

Revenues for the quarter were $87.05 billion, a 14% increase compared to Q3 2024. Last year, revenues improved by 13%, so this means that Alphabet not only is growing, but it is doing so even faster. This is impressive since this company has a market cap over $3 trillion and it grows like a small-medium cap company. At this point, I really don’t know what the limit is, it might even reach $10-20 trillion over the long term.

Google Search & Other, which was supposed to be obsolete a couple of quarters ago, continue to grow by double digits (+15%) and reached $56.56 billions of revenues. In hindsight, we can definitely affirm that ChatGPT hasn't even scratched the Mountain View giant. Actually, Google Search is growing faster and Gemini reached 650 million monthly active users. The market is gradually understanding that AI is not a threat, but an opportunity to get the best out of every business segment of this company, including Google Search:

AI is driving an expansionary moment and transforming how people use Google Search. Our investments in new AI experiences, such as AI Overviews and AI Mode, continued to drive growth in overall queries, including commercial queries, creating more opportunities for monetization. These AI experiences are enhancing how people connect with businesses and shop on Search. We recently added shopping capabilities in AI Mode, which now help people shop conversationally in Search, and we expanded try-on capabilities to more clothing items, now available to anyone in the U.S.

Philipp Schindler, Senior Vice President & Chief Business Officer of Google.

What Philipp Schindler described is basically the reason why Alphabet is among the best companies in the world: it constantly evolves to meet the changing needs of its users and it never gets stuck on what worked in the past. Successful long-term investments require a forward-looking approach, something that is embedded in the Google’s vision.

Now let’s talk about YouTube, of which revenues reached $10.26 billion, a 15% increase year-over-year. In this case as well, the growth rate accelerated, and during the conference call, Philipp Schindler provided interesting insights about the future of this platform.

So in other words, on average, a YouTube Music and Premium subscriber generates a meaningful higher gross profit than they were simply an ad-supported users. Fans come from all over the world. You know this and this engagement through ads and subscription generates YouTube's revenues and funds what I started with, these creators here and this then drives more viewership and engagement and so on. And that's the flywheel.

YouTube initially started with an ad-based business model, but the main goal is making it a subscription-based model. The latter guarantees recurring revenues, regardless the business cycle, and these kinds of businesses tend to be trading at high price multiples. Furthermore, the gross profit on Premium subscribers is way higher than ad-supported users, and this means high profitability. Current paid subscriptions are over 300 million, mainly driven by Google One and YouTube Premium.

The improvement in profitability is already visible in the operating margin, 42.53% (excluding the $3.50 billion EC fine) compared to 40.30% of Q3 2024. Clearly, besides YouTube Premium, much of this margin expansion has been led by the Google Cloud.

Revenues grew by 34%, but operating income has shot up by 85% since it is a highly scalable business. Alphabet will greatly benefit from the operating leverage of this business, and we are still in an early phase. Consider that a mature cloud like AWS can deliver an operating margin of about 40%, almost double than Google Cloud. Currently, Google Cloud makes up less than 10% of total operating income, but its share is bound to get much wider.

Our complete enterprise AI product portfolio is accelerating growth in revenue, operating margins and backlog. In Q3, customer demand strengthened in 3 ways. One, we are signing new customers faster. The number of new GCP customers increased by nearly 34% year-over-year. Two, we are signing larger deals. We have signed more deals over $1 billion through Q3 this year than we did in the previous 2 years combined. Third, we are deepening our relationships. Over 70% of existing Google Cloud customers use our AI products, including Banco BV, Best Buy and FairPrice Group.

Sundar Pichai, CEO & Director.

When you have a business with such a high growth potential and it might reach an operating income of 40-50% over the long term, no wonder why the company increased CapEx once again.

Overall, I am fully satisfied by these Q3 2025 results as Alphabet is becoming a diversified giant. Initially, the whole business relied on Google Search & Other, now we have YouTube Premium and Google Cloud that provide recurring revenues with a high profitability. Plus, they are both growing faster than Google Search.

A matter of valuation

As previously stated, Alphabet remains my #1 position in my portfolio, but its valuation is getting a bit overextended, that’s the reason behind the hold rating. I wouldn’t sell a single share since I plan to hold this great company for the long term (at least 10 years), but at the same time I wouldn’t buy at the current levels.

I think investors had a pretty long-time span (multiple occasions over the last 3 years) to buy some shares, and now it might be too late to jump on the bandwagon. I understand that fundamentals are improving faster than expected, but at this point I think FOMO is starting to set in. Alphabet was traded at $200 just 2 months ago, most of the year even below that threshold. Now everyone wants Alphabet and it seems cheap at $300 per share. But what kind of growth rate the current valuation is pricing in?

Starting from the TTM free cash flow and considering a RRR of 12%, to justify the $300 per share, the company should deliver a 10Y CAGR of 23.50%. So, this means a $607 billion free cash flow by 2035, and a market cap of $12 trillion if we assume a 20x price multiple. Is it possible? Yes. Is it likely? It might be.

I would never bet against Alphabet, but at the same time I would wait a drop before jumping in once again. The expectations are getting pretty high and we know how unpredictable the future is: the current valuation is not pricing in any unexpected event. Of course, I hope I am wrong and my unrealized profits keep spiking up.
